text: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed very brown amber with a medium sized white head. Toast, citrus but musky and faint, toast. Medium bodied, toast, a bit of bitterness, citrus, toast. Citrus on the finish, faintly bitter with lingering grapefruit zestu. Weird because theres not a ton going on here in any direction, comes across as a somewhat conflicted beer, pulling in about four or five directions. Wants to be hoppy, but isnt, wants to be malty, citrusy, bitter, but isnt. Decent, but ultimately forgettable as it never makes its mark in any way. Dont get me wrong, its still tasty and drinkable, and you can likely drink a bunch of them and be happy since it will satisfy something different each time, but Im having a hard time pinning it down for one thing that stands out in any notable measure that makes me want to seek it out specifically again. Ultimately thats ok, its still tasty enough.

Draft pour at ChurchKey, thanks solidfunk! Hazy amber with off-white head. Aromas of citrus, floral, tropical fruit. Tastes of citrus, tropical fruit, floral notes. Medium body with a dry finish. Tastes more like a pale.
LBssically a pale ale but they decided to call it amber like your red head sister gave birth. Some citrus. Good for style. Murky amber pour. Bitter finish. Tap at Churchkey.
Draft. Murky dark amber body topped by medium off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, lemon, dank, light grapefruit. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some caramel, light dank. Light-medium body.
Can, thanks JC. Nice hoppy aroma, taste is similar, bit of bitterness, bit of bitter type maltiness. Quite nice. God knows what I was talking about here.
Very cloudy amber brown color. Odd vegatale, chocolate and citrusy nose. The mouth is all over the place. Not very focused. Meh whatever

Can at home. Pours cloudy amber with a good beige head. Aroma is fruity with pineapple and peach, get a bit of citrus and pine as well. Taste is tropical fruits, citrus, pine needles and a nice caramel sweetness from the malts. Quite low carbonation, very smooth mouthfeel.

On tap @ Bissell Brothers. Super, super cloudy amber color with off-white foam. Was nowhere near as big a fan of this as the other drafts I tried during my visit. Does at least have some tropical and citrusy hops, but its heavy on the toast and caramel malts. Has some pepper, wood, and grassy hops notes and bitterness. Eh.

Tall can from jc1762. Hazy burnt orange hue with big, puffed up tan head. Nose is citrus and hops and fruits. Taste is also lots of hops, floral notes and citrus. Quite a kick to it. Very nice with grapefruit in the sweet finish. A great Ale.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2016 Can poured into a snifter showing really dark sewer looking brown with two fingers of tanned brown foam. This looks interesting. 

The nose shows subtle notes of pine resin. Upon warming up strong notes of cannabis become very apparent.

The palate is medium bodied and moderately carbonated. Feels somewhat sediment-y. Flavors of bready malts and not much else. Light bitterness on the finish with a resurgence of the bready malts.
On draft at the brewey it is an unfiltered apple cider color with an off white head. The aroma is citrus and the taste is strong nutty with hints of orange and finishes bitteri
On draft at the brewery. Pours a murky amber with an off white head. Light bready citrus aroma. Flavors of nuts and orange peel. Bitter finish.

Nice tropical hop aroma with a dank finish. Good amount of malt but hops still very prominent. Cloudy and unfiltered. Looks like apple cider. Finishes with dank hops, but not resinous. A bit low carbonation, but flavorful and a nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewery. Milky Amber pour with a white head. I typically dont like amber ales, but this is an exception. Muted bitter orange, grapefruit, and citrus hop notes yield to caramel malt backbeats. Good body and mouthfeel.

Draft at the source. 

Super murky rusty orange / brown body. Tan collar with copious lacing. Malty, fruity, dank hop aroma. Sweet malt leaps out with ripened fruits and a note of sweet breads. Medium bitterness.

Draught at the Thirsty Pig, 7/10/16.Just a hilariously ugly, muddy, drab, mauve-dark amber. Beige head atop is large and well-retained. The first New England-style amber IPA Ive seen.Juiciness is there in force, with cherry, melon, lime and kiwi confronted by a pleasing graininess from the specialty malts. Fresh yeast adding lots of minerality and light earth with a hint of ash on the end. But the juicy, fruity, succulent hops persist and are joined by light honey-vanilla-caramel suggestions, softening the graininess somewhat. No alcohol or flaw.Very soft texture with ample, tight carbonation and plentiful citrus notes mixing with melon, cherry and sweet lime. Graininess almost becomes problematic/scratchy but not quite and it actually dries out and balances the base malt and hugely juicy, fruity hops nicely. More citrus lingering on the end with moderate to moderately-high (but still tolerable) bitterness and no alcohol or flaw.
Murky red brown. Aroma is citrusy hops. Fruity and slight toffee malt. Good stuff tough to do an amber of this style and not have it be word, like it

On tap at the brewerys new location. Slightly hazy medium amber pour with frothy head. Interesting cracker and malt sensations with some floral and pine notes. Medium body. Smooth malt start in the taste with a nice spicy, floral, and pine bitterness that ends soft.

Sampled at the brewery, pours a murky, dark orange. Nose has Parmesan rind, dried orange peel, malt, mild nuts. Flavor is sweet, dark honey, orange peel, a little caramel, tobacco leaf, vegetal. Dry finish.

Sample at Bissell Brothers with koleminer20. Aroma is malt, bread, tropical fruit, pine, very hoppy. Appearance is ugly, amber brown copper, light tan head, hazy. Taste is juicy, tropical fruit, bitter malt, caramel, bready, good. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light crisp carbonation, bready fruit aftertaste. Overall, solid solid amber.

On tap at Bissell Brothers. The pour is a messy light orange-tinted Amber brown color with a big bubbly ivory head that falls to a collar leaving a ton of lace. The aroma is just what youd expect in an Amber. There is a light sweet maltiness and a little leafy hop present on the back end. Thats about it here. Basic and light, but thats what an Amber is. The flavor is really juicy hop right up front that makes this drink like the ugliest IPA youve ever seen. The malts come in about half way through and a lighter caramel sweetness carries it out to the finish. The mouth feel is a little thicker and well carbonated with a juicy citrus tinted caramel malt lingering on the aftertaste. This is ugly as hell to look at, but it does well.

On draft directly from one of the Bissell Brothers (or at least someone who works there). Hop-forward and pungent, like all BB beers, but this one is probably one of their most subdued offerings. Maltier, darker, and less hoppy than their pale ales and IPAs. It smelled incredible, but the taste was a little to low-key for what I was looking for from Bissell.

Tap at Bissell Brothers Brewing Company, Portland. Originally rated 20160220. Colour is cloudy murky almost mud like with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Chocolate, caramel, grain, hops and malts. Very strange looking beer but I like it. Drinkability very good.

Can at home. Pours a pretty muddy brick-red; honestly, it kind of looks like Georgia red clay mop water, and thats the only knock against it. Great nose: piney, orange peel, grapefruit, baked bread, a little toffee. Very well-crafted; strikingly creamy texture.
Amber and white head pour from draft at Kingshead. Carmel and hops. Sweet with malt fruits. Good stuff.

Can from the brewery. It pours crazy murky brown with gigantic off-white head. The nose is juicy, beer - sweet, toffee, orange sherbet, stewed peach, icing sugar, charry pine and resin. The taste is bitter, woody, earthy, pine, orange peel, peach, pepper, resin and varnish with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. A bit dirty, but I sort of like it...

16oz tall boy can thanks to JohnGonk. Pours a dark cloudy reddish/brown color with a finger of foamy beige head. Aroma of caramel malt, rotted citrus, red grape skins, and toasted grains. Taste is much the same. Rotted citrus, toasted and burnt grain, red grapes, caramel malt, and some earthy grassiness.

Refrigerated 16 oz. aluminum can fro AirForceHops poured into a nonic. Hazy deep amber with medium beige head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, medium carbonation, and some medium-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel malt, fresh herbal hops, some pine hops, and bitter finish. Nice amber ale.

Draft sample at the source. Murky light brown, big lacing. Hoppy pine and caramel, some fruit. Smooth with some resin. Excellent hoppy Amber 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from Tullys in Wells, ME. Dark reddish brown pour. Thin off-white head. Sparse lacing. Nose is caramel toffee, nice piney notes with hints of moss and dirt. Taste is reasonably balanced; malty up front with some nice piney hop bitterness. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Decent brew.

16 oz. can purchased at Tullys in Wells, ME. Serious deep red color/ honestly damn near brown. Aroma very deep earthy hops sitting on top caramel. 
The flavor is has the expected toasted grain and caramel malt with a high hop profile. The hops are earthy and herbal with maybe a hint of pine. The texture is gritty and dry. Anybody who knows me understand I feel like Amber ales are very ordinary and plain. Bissell Bros. manages to make a highly drinkable Amber with this hop profile. This is about top tier in the style for my palate.

Can. Pours murky brown with a thin white head that coats the brew. Malt comes through nicely and is complemented by hop bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Northeast Bucket List Trip Beer #88. Keg at the brewery. Pours a hazy red amber with a large frothy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of caramel malt, floral and tropical hops. The taste is tropical, pine, citrus hops, caramel malt. Medium bodied, mild lingering bitterness.

Medium amber and cloudy; thin, lasting off-white head. Hops and citrus on the nose. Instant pine needles when you sip, medium finish. medium body, lively carbonation. Overall its quite tasty but not my favorite.
Draft at York River Landing. Pours orange golden brown with a clingy off white head. Aroma is pine, citrus, peach. Taste is a buttery caramel backbone with citrus, pine hop. Good balance.

Draft at Pai Men Miyake. A bit of a let down after Substance but Im usually not a big fan of ambers. Aroma of peach, citrus, mango. Not overly dry, some lingering sweetness. Slightly buttery. Decent citrus and tropical fruit notes with a decent amount of caramel. I really wish I visited this brewery but I guess it is more reason to come back.

Can. Pours a deep straw color, white bubbles. Aroma is light mango and heavy grapefruit with super dank Simcoe notes. Taste is grapefruit, orange, and mango with sweet malts and light pine. Really good.
draft at Bissell Brothers, Portland, Maine. amber pour, medium bodied. malt forward, citrusy bitterness. solid amber

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2015 On tap at brewery. Hazy copper color with off white head. Aroma is citrus, fruity peach , pine and slight onion. Fruity malt start with citrus followed by peach flavors, citrus sweetness, and some onion finishing with grapefruit and pine. Some lingering bitterness. Truly the hi-light of my Maine trip..

Pours a hazy dull copper sienna color with a couple fingers of tight eggshell foam. Punchy citrus, dank pine, solid malt bill with nuances of toasted grain, round dusty wheat and sharp a bitterness as the pine sap notes take hold of the finish. The grain structure is lost a bit towards the finish and some slight astringent weirdness of flavors linger.
